Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was touched inappropriately by a staff member during a
restraint. Youth A could not name the staff member other than
noting he was a black male with a skinny build that normally did
not work in her program.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 06/21/2023 and had no
additional information to offer.
Youth A was interviewed through a video conference child
advocacy center interview with DHHS Worker 1 and law
enforcement on 07/20/2023. Youth A recalled there was a time
when she was restrained when she experienced something she
felt was concerning. Youth A stated she was restrained by one
male staff member, who she could not name but knew it wasn’t
Staff 1, and that he did not normally work on her site but at
another site within the same program. She reported the male staff
member touched his hand on the top of her thigh. She believed
his hand moved to the inside of her thigh. Youth A recalled fighting
this restraint and believed this may have been the cause for where
his hand touched her. She stated the staff member was not saying
anything at that time. Youth A stated she did not think that this
was meant to be inappropriate because of all the movement
involved in the restraint. Youth A was asked again about anyone
else, staff or other youths, that could have witnessed this incident
and she stated she did not think anyone else witnessed this.
Youth A also could not give a specific or approximate timeframe
on when this occurred, only that it occurred after 02/14/2023.
Therapist 1 was interviewed on 08/08/2023 during an announced
face-to-face visit to the facility. Documentation including staff
schedules was reviewed and it was concluded that there was not
sufficient information available to determine who the staff member
was that Youth A referred to in her interview.
2

Documentation reviewed:
• Incident reports spanning the full dates of the placement of
Youth A were reviewed and none matched the description
of the restraint.
Analysis Through interviews of staff and youth there was no evidence
found that Youth A was touched inappropriately during a restraint.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth’s behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition, medical
condition, psychiatric condition, and personal history,
including any history of trauma, and must be done in a
manner consistent with the youth’s treatment plan.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A experienced an injury as a result of the restraint because
Staff 3 held her feet down to the ground forcefully.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed through a video conference child
advocacy center interview with DHHS Worker 1 and law
enforcement on 07/20/2023. Youth A struggled to recall the
specifics of the incident. She recalled there was one time when
she was treated for a sprained ankle. Youth A stated she ran
away from the building into the woods because she was upset.
She believed she was restrained while running away in the woods.
Youth A stated she could not remember when this incident
occurred, but she knew it was during the winter because there
was snow on the ground. She believed she was outside for a long
time because it eventually got dark. Youth A recalled Staff 1, Staff
3 and Therapist 1 were present. Youth A was asked to describe
the restraint. She stated she could not remember which staff were
involved in the hands-on portion of the restraint, but that there was
one staff by her stomach, and one by each arm as she was on the
ground. Youth A could not recall how she went from being on her
feet to the ground. She stated the entire restraint lasted about a
minute. Youth A first stated she was on her stomach during the
restraint, but then clarified that she was on her back and was not
ever face down. Youth A stated she was not sure if this is when
she hurt her ankle, but she knew she hurt her ankle that day when
she was outside at some point. Youth A stated Staff 1 grabbed her
shirt, and she threw a punch at him. She stated she thought Staff
1 swung back at her with an open fist. She proceeded to kick him
before being taken to the ground for a restraint. Youth A stated
3

she believed her ankle was hurt during the restraint itself, because
Staff 3 was pushing on her feet. She recalled she was
continuously kicking back at staff while she was on the ground
being restrained. Youth A stated she got in Staff 3’s car with other
staff that she could not recall and was transported back to the
facility. Youth A stated she refused to go back inside. She was
eventually sent to the local hospital because she had been talking
about wanting to kill herself.
Therapist 1 was interviewed on 08/22/2023 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit at the facility. Therapist 1
stated that she could not remember what staff were with Youth A
or if Youth A was restrained. Therapist 1 stated she encountered
Youth A after Youth A was transported back to the facility from the
woods. Therapist 1 stated she did not hear Youth A say anything
about her ankle hurting, and never heard anything about Youth A
falling in the woods or being restrained. Therapist 1 stated she
had concern for Youth A because of Youth A was making
statements of self-harm and attempt suicide. Therapist 1 made the
decision to send Youth A out to receive medical attention.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/22/2023 during an announced face-
to-face visit at the facility with DHHS Worker 1. Staff 1 recalled
being a part of the 02/14/2023 incident with Youth A. He stated he
went outside to attempt to provide line of sight supervision of
Youth A when she was walking away from the building. Staff 1
stated he did not believe they came back inside for a long time.
Staff 1 believed Staff 2 was with him. Youth A refused to come
inside, and he and Staff 2 were attempting to de-escalate and
convince her to come back to the building. Staff 1 stated Staff 3
came to assist at some point. Staff 1 told Youth A they had to
escort her back to the building. He stated a standing restraint was
initiated where two staff members were on either side of Youth A
holding her arms. Staff 1 stated this did not last long as Youth A
was fighting. It proceeded to a ground restraint where he and one
of the other staff involved had contact with Youth A’s arms, and
the third staff had her legs in their hands. Staff 1 could not recall
who was holding what area of Youth A’s body during their
restraint. Staff 1 stated he does not remember anything about
Youth A hurting her ankle while being outside or while being
restrained. He stated he did not see her limping at any point and
did not hear her say anything about her ankle hurting.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 08/30/2023. She stated
it had been a while since she worked at the facility, but she
recalled the incident. Staff 2 stated she had been outside with
4

Youth A for hours with Staff 1 and Staff 3. Staff 2 remembered
following Youth A outside of the facility to far reaching areas of the
property to provide line of sight supervision, all while it was cold
and there was snow on the ground. Staff 2 recalled Youth A was
not wearing a coat. Staff 2 stated Youth A started hitting and
screaming at staff when the restraint began. She also recalled
Youth A stating that she wanted to kill herself several times. She
could not recall the specifics of how the restraint was performed.
She remembered hearing Youth A state that the only way she was
going to return to the facility was that staff were going to have to
“take her down.” Staff 2 stated the reason she and Staff 1 decided
to attempt a restraint was Youth A was sitting in the snow, it was
dark, and she had been outside for hours and she had not shown
any reason for staff to believe that she was going to listen to their
requests to come back inside the facility. In addition, Staff 2 did
not believe Youth A hurt her ankle at any point and did not see her
limping. She stated she was the staff at the hospital with Youth A
later in the evening and did not recall Youth A’s ankle coming up
as a concern.
Attempts were made to contact Staff 3 on 08/29/2023, 08/30/2023
and 09/01/2023 with no return calls. Staff 3 is no longer employed
for the facility.
Documents reviewed:
• Medical documentation for Youth A of a visit to emergency
care center on 02/14/2023. This documentation described
Youth A was transported to the hospital by ambulance for a
mental health evaluation. It stated Youth A described ankle
pain from “rolling her right ankle while running in the
woods.” An x-ray was performed with no fractures or
dislocation. Youth A was encouraged to rest her ankle and
ice it as a plan of treatment for the injury.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as through interviews and
documents reviewed, there was no evidence that staff caused an
injury while restraining Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency Restraint
Section The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others
from an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that
places the youth or others at serious threat of violence or
injury if no immediate intervention occurs.
5

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was placed in an unwarranted restraint on 02/14/2023.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed through a video conference child
advocacy center interview with DHHS Worker 1 and law
enforcement on 07/20/2023. Youth A stated on 02/14/2023 she
was restrained in the woods when she refused to come inside.
Youth A recalled sitting in a field at one point during the interaction
with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 near her. Youth A could not
provide specific details on why she was restrained. She recalled
staff had been asking her to come back to the building because it
was cold, getting late and starting to get dark and she
continuously refused to do so. Youth A stated she fought back
against Staff 1 once he initiated a restraint.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/22/2023 during an announced face-
to-face visit at the facility with DHHS Worker 1. He described the
course of events that led up to the restraint of Youth A on
02/14/2023. Staff 1 stated he had been following Youth A outside
of the facility for some time and she had not yet listened to his
requests she come back to the facility. Staff 1 stated the situation
carried on until it was getting dark, and they had ended up in a
spot-on campus where there was little light. He noted this
occurred in late winter and Youth A was not wearing a coat at the
time. Staff 1 stated he attempted to restrain Youth A when she
was sitting on the ground and Staff 1 approached her to lift her up.
He told her several times she needed to come back to the building
with staff and that if she did not cooperate, he would have to put
his hands on her to do so. He stated she stood up under her own
power, Staff 1 had his hands on Youth A's arm, and Youth A
began to kick at him. Staff 1 stated Youth A never attempted to
punch him, and he never attempted to punch her back.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 08/30/2023. Staff 2
stated she had been outside with Youth A for hours with Staff 1
and Staff 3. Staff 2 remembered following Youth A outside of the
facility to far reaching areas of the property to provide line of sight
supervision, all while it was cold and there was snow on the
ground. Staff 2 recalled Youth A was not wearing a coat. Staff 2
recalled Youth A hitting her and Staff 1 as the restraint began. She
could not confirm if Youth A had attempted to hit herself, Staff 1 or
Staff 2 prior to the restraint beginning. Staff 2 remembered
hearing Youth A say the only way she was going to return to the
facility was that staff were going to have to “take her down.” Staff
2 stated the reason she and Staff 1 decided to attempt a restraint
was that Youth A was sitting in the snow, it was dark and she had
6

been outside for hours and she had not shown any reason for staff
to believe that she was going to listen to their requests to come
inside.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Behavior Support and Management
Policy (BSM)” was provided and referenced. This policy
stated that “Non-violent physical intervention is defined as a
staff member’s use of physical control to contain a client’s
acute physical behavior. Acute physical behavior is defined
by any behavior that is likely to result in physical injury or
imminent risk of physical harm of the client, other clients,
staff members, or others.”
Analysis Through interviews with staff and youth as well as documentation
reviewed there was evidence to show that the restraint performed
on 02/14/2023 was not warranted as the youth was not presenting
behaviors that risked immediate harm.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification;
Section debriefing; reporting.
Description (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form
prescribed by the department for each incident involving the
use of seclusion or restraint. The initial report shall be
submitted to the department within 24 hours of the incident
occurring. A final incident report shall be submitted no later
than 72 hours after the incident has occurred.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation No incident report exists for the restraint that occurred of Youth A
on 02/14/23.
Investigation Through separate interviews, Youth A, Staff 1 and Staff 2 all
stated Youth A was restrained on 02/14/2023. Staff 1 stated that
he was sure an incident report was written but that he could not
recall if he, Staff 2 or Staff 3 authored it. Staff 2 could not recall
writing an incident report for the restraint in question. Therapist 1
confirmed on 08/24/2023 that an incident report could not be
located.
Documents reviewed:
• A shift log from 02/14/2023 was provided and reviewed. It
stated Youth A, Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 were involved in
an incident where Youth A AWOL’ed from the facility and
was restrained in the woods to then be brought back to the
facility and eventually the hospital.
7

Analysis Through interviews of youth and staff as well as documentation
reviewed there was evidence found of a lack of documentation of
a restraint of Youth A that occurred on 02/14/2023.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
